title: Company births and deaths: investigating the role of taxation
abstractText:
This research project aims to shed new light on the impact of corporation tax on the creation and destruction of new companies, and on the behaviour of small companies. We will exploit three UK tax reforms between 1999 and 2006: the rate of corporation tax faced by small companies was reduced from 20 per cent to 10 per cent, then to zero, before being raised again to 19 per cent. We will exploit confidential, newly available, data from the HMRC Datalab on the corporation tax assessments of the universe of UK companies.

A substantial number of new companies were created around the period of the low rate of tax. We aim to identify the role of taxation in inducing these company births, as well as the also substantial number of company dissolutions. We will compare the new companies with existing companies. In particular, the incentive for unincorporated firms to incorporate differs across different levels of profit: we aim to identify the extent to which new companies simply took advantage of the low starting rate. We will also investigate whether the lower starting rate induced a higher rate of corporate investment.
impactText:
This main scientific impact to date has been through the paper: Devereux, M.P., L. Liu and S. Loretz (2012) "The elasticity of corporate taxable income: evidence from UK tax records", published in the American Economic Journal: Economic Policy. 

We organised a Special Session in the 2013 Royal Economics Society Annual Meeting to highlight the importance of using administrative data for research in taxation and policy making, at which the paper was presented. We have also presented the paper at a number of other international academic conferences, including the Design and Impact of Tax Reform Conference in Vienna (October 5, 2012), the 7th Biennial Meeting of Hong Kong Economics Association (December 14, 2012) and the 16th UNC Tax Symposium (January 25, 2013). 

As a first step towards wider societal impact, we have also discussed our research and its policy implications with a wide audience in policy making. We gave formal presentations at the 2nd International Conference on Taxation Analysis and Research (December 2-3, 2011), the HMRC Inter-departmental Meeting (September 5, 2012), the HMRC/HMT/ESRC Joint Research Programme on Taxation Analysis Event (December 7, 2012) and the Launch of the ESRC/HMRC/HMT Tax Administration Research Centre (February 12, 2013). We have also discussed our research findings informally with several representatives of CBT network of contacts, inside and outside of government. We also met HMRC officials on several occasions during the course of the project, to discuss our approach, and to share ideas.

We have prepared non-technical summaries of the studies addressing policy questions. We have circulated this material widely to a non-academic audience, including the Centre's mailing list of over 1000 people, including senior officials in HM Treasury and HMRC, in international organisations such as the IMF and OECD, and also tax experts in business and professional firms. 

As originally proposed, we have presented the research to a Centre for Business Taxation conference. We have also presented it to a non-technical audience at another Centre conference in 2013. And we have presented the research at a one-day HMRC- Centre for Business Taxation workshop. Government, Democracy and Justice Economic,Policy & public services
findingsText:
This research project analyses the response of small businesses to corporation tax, using a dataset that merges newly available confidential tax return data from the HRMC Datalab with accounting data. 

First, we investigate the elasticity of corporate taxable profit with respect to the tax rate. Under certain circumstances this elasticity can be a "sufficient statistic" for evaluating the costs to society generated by the tax. We use a technique proposed by Saez (2010) to estimate this elasticity, by analysing the extent to which companies "bunch" at kinks in the marginal tax rate schedule. Further, for companies where owner/managers are able to take income as salary or profit, we decompose the elasticity into an effect on the total income of the company and an effect on the share declared as profit. We derive the first estimates of the welfare cost of corporate taxation in the UK. 

We estimate that the elasticity of corporate taxable profit to be between 0.14 and 0.18 for companies with profits around the ?300k kink in the marginal tax rate schedule, implying a marginal deadweight cost of 8% of revenue. We find a much higher elasticity of between 0.54 and 0.57 for companies around the ?10k kink. Decomposing this into two parts, we estimate an elasticity of total income with respect to the net of tax rate of between 0.2 and 0.3, and an elasticity of the share of income taken as profit with respect to the difference between the personal and corporate tax rates of between 0.04 and 0.07. Together these imply a marginal deadweight cost of the tax around ?10k of around 29% of revenue. We find no evidence of inter-temporal shifting of profit.

The second study concerns the incorporation decision of small businesses. Because we do not have access to data on unincorporated businesses, we use the merged data set to identify the total income each small company earns. We then identify (a) the minimum total tax that the owner could pay, conditional on the business being incorporated; (b) the actual tax that the owner paid; and (c) the tax that the owner would have paid had his business been unincorporated. This approach allows us to make inferences about the extent to which incorporation decisions reflect differences in the tax treatment between the different forms of business.
